Award.AwardTitle: OP: Collaborative Research: Nanoscale Synthesis, Characterization and Modeling of Rationally Designed Plasmonic Materials and Architectures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Description: This collaborative and interdisciplinary project brings together both experimentalists and theorists to explore advanced optical materials and devices. This is accomplished using new materials processing methods, advanced characterization techniques, and state-of-the-art theoretical/computational models. The materials and devices have practical applications such as improved solar energy conversion, chemical sensors, and faster as well as higher data storage capacity for computing. The project explores new material combinations and architectures to optimize the way different frequencies of light can be harnessed and manipulated. Advanced materials processing methods are developed to create complex two-dimensional and three-dimensional arrangements of these optical materials. One goal of the project is to train both graduate and undergraduate students to function in a collaborative and interdisciplinary environment. To accomplish this, the graduate students work closely with the collaborating institutions which cross-cut several research areas: materials synthesis (materials science and engineering), materials characterization (chemistry), and theory/simulation (chemistry and applied mathematics). Undergraduate students are impacted by the development of a new multi-institutional and interdisciplinary design project.

Technical Description: The overarching goal of this activity is to study new plasmonic materials and architectures for advanced optical and metamaterial concepts with a broad spectral tunability across the visible and near-IR. This goal is realized via the execution of three overarching objectives. The first objective comprises a systematic study of the synthesis, characterization, and theory/modeling of Au-Al, Ag-Al binary, and Au-Ag-Al ternary alloys with the goal of correlating the materials nanostructure to the fundamental optical properties and full plasmonic spectrum. The second objective aims to rationally design, synthesize, and characterize innovative 2D plasmonic nanoarchitectures that incorporate multi-material dimer/oligomer systems, templated substrates that induce asymmetric dielectric coupling, and advanced lithographic/focused ion beam nanomachining for pushing the limits of small size/narrow gaps. The third objective seeks understanding of the far- and near-field optical properties of new 3D plasmonic nanoarchitectures synthesized via focused electron beam induced processing. These objectives are accomplished via a highly collaborative and multi-disciplinary approach which brings together distinctive expertise in the areas of thin film and nanoscale synthesis and characterization, optical and electron-beam plasmon spectroscopy, and advanced theory/simulation of optical- and electron-induced localized surface plasmon resonance phenomena. The multidisciplinary program provides a unique learning experience for both undergraduate and graduate student participants. Additionally, a new multi-disciplinary and multi-institutional design project extends this experience to other undergraduate students at all three participating institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Localized surface plasmon resonances (LSPRs) sustained by metallic nanostructures have the ability harness light into nanoscale dimensions and significantly impact the local electromagnetic field at the surface of single and few nanoparticle systems. The electromagnetic field that is generated is highly dependent on the characteristics of the underlying system and a significant amount of work remains to be done to correlate the optical properties of nanomaterials to the physical properties of the materials that comprise the system. The interdisciplinary work undertaken in this grant seeks to elucidate the optical properties of single and multidimensional metallic materials through a combination of novel materials fabrication methods, ultra-high resolution microscopy and spectroscopy techniques, and state-the-art theoretical and computational modeling. In particular, this project explored the plasmonic responses of new multi-metal alloy combinations and complex 2-D and 3-D nanoarchitectures and developed novel methods to probe these systems.

The optical properties of binary metallic systems were investigated via the combinatorial sputtering of Au-Al thin films of various compositions and thicknesses. The dielectric properties of these materials were shown to be tunable across a broad spectrum of IR, visible, and UV energies depending on the materials partial composition of metals. Additional comparisons of as-deposited and laser annealed thin-films demonstrated how the optical response varied as the phase and crystallographic structure of the material changed. Finally, these materials were shown to have active LSPR hotspots through a simple SERS analysis of a simple reporter molecule, lending credence to the utility of a tunable dielectric function.

This work has directly contributed to the development of two scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) compatible methods for measuring the dynamic states induced by photoexcitation of optically active nanomaterials, providing two new experimental techniques for the characterization of these novel materials. In the first method, a new optical delivery system provides >200 mW of optical power to a <4 nm spot directly to a STEM sample. The optical system can selectively activate various thermal pathways by controlling the laser power, pulse width, pulse frequency, and radial position. The long optical working distance mitigates any charging artifacts and tremendous thermal stability is observed in both pulsed and continuous wave conditions, notably, no drift correction is applied in any experiment. The second technique demonstrates a novel approach for experimentally accessing the photon-stimulated excited states of plasmonic nanoparticles by combining a constant wavelength laser in an electron energy loss/gain spectroscopic measurement. Stimulated gain and loss probabilities increase linearly in the low-irradiance range and more importantly demonstrate the plasmon-photon coupling between an incident laser and a metallic nanorod.

The results of this project were made possible by the highly collaborative and multi-disciplinary approach that combined expertise in materials science (Philip Rack), optical- and electron-spectroscopy (Jon Camden), and theoretical/simulated analysis (David Masiello). In addition to the scientific advances enabled here, the PIs, postdoctoral, and Ph.D. students received state-of-the-art training and enriched their scientific perspectives via the research team’s effort.
